quotes.topic_title: Cold open: promotion denial, leadership, meetings tease
quotes.text: Hope for the future is so important.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A simple principle for delivering bad news while keeping the person motivated and engaged.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: promotion denial, leadership, meetings tease
quotes.text: I know this is going to be challenging for you to hear, not going to promote you, but I want you to know this.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A direct script for starting a promotion denial conversation with empathy and clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: promotion denial, leadership, meetings tease
quotes.text: It's really important to me that you're able to succeed in your career here, and so I want to continue to help you find opportunities to build your skills and to advance.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Shows how to pair a “no” with a concrete commitment to development and future growth paths.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: promotion denial, leadership, meetings tease
quotes.text: They're trying now to be the leader who everyone loves, but what really needs to happen very often is, we need to drive towards results.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that leadership effectiveness is about outcomes, not popularity.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: promotion denial, leadership, meetings tease
quotes.text: Ultimately, that leads to the demise of your company.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A stark consequence statement that underscores why avoiding hard feedback is organizationally dangerous.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: What I love about Alisa is that she gives her clients very specific and actionable advice.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the practical, scriptable nature of Alisa’s coaching approach—useful for practitioners seeking concrete language and tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In her conversation, Alisa shares specific language and phrases that you can use when having a difficult conversation with your reports to make these conversations go much smoother and be less difficult.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Promises reusable scripts for hard conversations, a directly applicable tool for managers.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, three questions you should ask at the end of every meeting to make the most possible forward progress after each meeting.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Introduces a repeatable meeting wrap-up framework aimed at improving execution and momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Plus, why your job as a leader isn't to make people happy and what you should be focused on instead,
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive leadership mindset shift that challenges the common “make everyone happy” management instinct.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: and a set of questions that she calls the founder prenup that you should talk through with potential founders to make sure that these are the people that you want to be working with for a long, long time.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Names a memorable alignment methodology (“founder prenup”) for de-risking co-founder relationships through structured questions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (host)
quotes.context: A clear practitioner takeaway on why teams should invest in experimentation as a core growth and product-learning capability.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo helps you increase experimentation velocity while unlocking rigorous deep analysis in a way that no other commercial tool does.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (host)
quotes.context: Highlights a practical dual-goal methodology for experimentation programs: move faster without sacrificing analytical rigor.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most was our experimentation platform where I could set up experiments, easily troubleshoot issues, and analyze all on my own.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (host)
quotes.context: A concrete example of self-serve experimentation enabling individual contributors to run end-to-end experiments without bottlenecks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more with advanced statistical methods that can help you shave weeks off experiment time and accessible UI for diving deeper into performance and out-of-the-box reporting that helps you avoid annoying prolonged analytic cycles.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (host)
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on what to look for in experimentation tooling: faster time-to-results plus built-in reporting to reduce analysis drag.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Just hired someone? Rippling makes onboarding easy. Whether your new hire is sitting next to you or halfway across the world, in just a few clicks, Rippling automatically generates an offer letter, ships a laptop with the necessary apps and permissions, and even delivers a corporate card.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (host)
quotes.context: A specific operational workflow example that teams can emulate: automate onboarding end-to-end across HR, IT, and spend.

quotes.topic_title: Why difficult conversations feel so hard
quotes.text: If I could ask you a question, if you're picturing a difficult conversation that you have had, should have, might have, and you're nervous about, it's hard for you, can you sum it up? What's hard about it? Because it's helpful to clarify what is hard about it?
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A practical coaching prompt to diagnose the specific fear driving avoidance, making the conversation easier to plan for.

quotes.topic_title: Why difficult conversations feel so hard
quotes.text: Just one more question on that. What's the problem if they're sad and upset? What does that mean to you?
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A reframing question that surfaces the hidden meaning/story you’re attaching to someone’s reaction.

quotes.topic_title: Why difficult conversations feel so hard
quotes.text: But we're putting meaning on things all the time, every day, all the time, and I think it's important, it's actually helpful in motivating you to have difficult conversations, but also in helping them go well. If you can get to the bottom of what you're putting on top of it, what you're weighting it with,
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A mental model: difficult conversations are hard largely because of the meaning you add—so reduce the “weight” to improve outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Why difficult conversations feel so hard
quotes.text: if you don't give them the opportunity to hear what you have to say, if you don't bring this up, then you're never going to have the opportunity to help them see something differently or help them improve or help you improve the relationship or whatever it is you're trying to do.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A counter to avoidance: not having the conversation removes the possibility of improvement for both the person and the relationship.

quotes.topic_title: Why difficult conversations feel so hard
quotes.text: No one wants to make anybody upset, but through that upset on the other side of that, can often be a whole new possibility and a whole new revelation, and actually a lot of joy and freedom.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A contrarian reframe that discomfort can be the gateway to better outcomes, not just collateral damage.

quotes.topic_title: Common hard conversation types and mindset
quotes.text: getting a difficult conversation is number one, tapping into what's uncomfortable for it, for you, about it. And then number two, also getting your mindset right.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A simple two-step framework for preparing: identify your discomfort, then reset your mindset before you speak.

quotes.topic_title: Common hard conversation types and mindset
quotes.text: Sometimes people are giving the performance feedback or talking about something that's been bothering them in order to express themselves and vent. And actually, that is very helpful to identify for yourself, that's why I'm doing it. And then, maybe not do it then, until you can transform your reasoning.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Actionable advice to pause hard feedback if your motive is venting, and only proceed once your intent is constructive.

quotes.topic_title: Common hard conversation types and mindset
quotes.text: But at the end of the day, the hope is as a manager, the reason that you're giving someone this so-called constructive feedback is because you're helping them get better. You need them to change the behavior. They'll never get promoted if they keep doing that. They'll never be successful if they keep doing that.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A mindset reframe that positions feedback as career-enabling rather than punitive, clarifying the manager’s responsibility.

quotes.topic_title: Common hard conversation types and mindset
quotes.text: The next day she came in and she said, "Thank you so much for telling me that. I wish someone had told me that 15 years ago. I think I could have had a different career."
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A vivid example showing that even emotional reactions (like crying) can coexist with deep gratitude for direct feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Common hard conversation types and mindset
quotes.text: But honestly, the only way you're going to be able to help someone grow in their career and become the best person they can be is by leaning into these tough conversations.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A memorable principle that challenges avoidance: growth requires leaning into discomfort, not steering around it.

quotes.topic_title: Script for performance feedback with peers
quotes.text: You know, Matilda, I want to chat with you about the way you're interacting with your peers. So what I'm hearing from them is that you're missing deadlines on a regular basis and not letting them know you're missing the deadlines, and that also you're not fully keeping your team up to speed.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A concrete opener that uses neutral framing (“what I’m hearing”) and specific behaviors to reduce defensiveness and anchor the feedback in observable impact.

quotes.topic_title: Script for performance feedback with peers
quotes.text: Now, we both know that the most important way you can be successful here and also achieve your goals is to make sure that you are working with your peers in a way that's consistent and that they can count on you and you can count on them.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Reframes feedback as shared expectations tied to the person’s success, creating alignment instead of a manager-vs-employee dynamic.

quotes.topic_title: Script for performance feedback with peers
quotes.text: I want to certainly hear what you have to say, but the most important thing is that we leave this discussion knowing how you're going to make sure that you're keeping your peers in the loop and also your team in the loop.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Sets a clear outcome for the conversation—leaving with a plan—so the discussion doesn’t end as vague feedback without next steps.

quotes.topic_title: Script for performance feedback with peers
quotes.text: The more even keeled and even matter of fact you can be about something that's kind of just run-of-the-mill feedback, the better.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A practical delivery principle: treating feedback as routine (not emotionally charged) increases the odds it’s heard and acted on.

quotes.topic_title: Script for performance feedback with peers
quotes.text: Because then, you've had the conversation with them to give them positive feedback and point out what's working, that builds the relationship so that you have the lens of, "Oh, yeah. When something's working, they tell me. When something's not working, they tell me, too." That's how you build trust as well.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A trust-building methodology: consistent positive + corrective feedback creates a reliable pattern that makes tough conversations easier to receive.

quotes.topic_title: When feedback is your observation, not hearsay
quotes.text: If you have a formula that can work for you, that's going to motivate you to do it, that is what's important. And what's important is that it's neutral, not loading on or not venting on someone and not unloading on someone.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A practical guideline for using repeatable scripts: consistency is fine as long as the delivery stays neutral and non-emotional.

quotes.topic_title: When feedback is your observation, not hearsay
quotes.text: What I've observed is that they can often be not as structured as I'd like them to be and they also lack a conclusion. So what I'd love you to do is look at these three or four examples of some folks who are doing them really well and see if you can model your writing on theirs.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A concrete example of observation-based feedback paired with a specific, actionable improvement path (modeling strong examples).

quotes.topic_title: When feedback is your observation, not hearsay
quotes.text: I think it's such an important point, observable facts. The idea that this is not a judgment.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for feedback: anchor on observable facts to reduce judgment and defensiveness.

quotes.topic_title: When feedback is your observation, not hearsay
quotes.text: I always ask my clients, what's my evidence that this is happening? And you have to spend some time thinking about it, but it's really worth it because it makes the feedback easier for you to give and easier for them to hear.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A repeatable coaching question that forces evidence-based feedback, improving clarity for both manager and employee.

quotes.topic_title: Handling defensiveness and emotional reactions
quotes.text: "Well, let's pause for a second. First of all, I want you to know that I'm telling you this actually, just to make you better because I know how important your career is to you. I know how important the success is to you and it's important to me too as your leader. The second thing is, my observation is that you're getting a little bit emotional. I want to know if we can continue having this conversation now or if we need to kind of pause it. At the end of the day, we really have to have this conversation and I really want to see you make changes, but I understand you might need a few moments to digest it."
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A ready-to-use script that de-escalates defensiveness by reaffirming intent, naming the emotional shift, and offering a choice to continue or pause.

quotes.topic_title: Handling defensiveness and emotional reactions
quotes.text: "The importance of that for you is not even what you say, but that you have prepared and you are prepared for if someone has that kind of reaction and that you don't have to, yourself, react to it."
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Emphasizes preparation as the key tool—so you can stay regulated and avoid getting pulled into an argument.

quotes.topic_title: Handling defensiveness and emotional reactions
quotes.text: "Now we're in a fight and that is not cool for anybody. It's certainly not cool for you as a leader. So it gives you the opportunity to recognize that you have another tool in your toolkit rather than just react."
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A mental model for leaders: pausing is a deliberate “tool” that prevents escalation into a fight.

quotes.topic_title: Handling defensiveness and emotional reactions
quotes.text: "When they're defensive, it's possible that you might want to use a different word. I can see that this is really upsetting you or this is really triggering you, or I can see that the temperature between us has just changed."
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Provides alternative phrasing to acknowledge emotion without labeling someone as “emotional,” reducing the chance of further defensiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Handling defensiveness and emotional reactions
quotes.text: "Ultimately, that kind of conversation has the potential to really build the relationship and build trust, and that's another reason I encourage everybody to get over their discomfort and to lean into having these conversations because on the other side of that, is a much better, stronger connection."
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Reframes hard feedback as a trust-building mechanism, not just a performance correction.

quotes.topic_title: Script for not granting a promotion
quotes.text: Yes, that hope for the future is so important and I think sometimes we're such in a rush to kind of deliver the bad news that we forget there's a human being over there who needs hope for the future.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Highlights a key delivery principle: pair a clear “no” with a credible future path so the person can stay motivated and resilient.

quotes.topic_title: Script for not granting a promotion
quotes.text: By the way, the other piece on that might be, if it's appropriate, I'd love you to digest this information and then let's talk about it again next week to see what you've come up with or see how you feel about it because you want to send, this is not the script, this is for me to you. You want to send the, I care about you message because that's the other thing.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Gives an actionable tactic—build in a follow-up after the initial “no”—to signal care and reduce emotional escalation.

quotes.topic_title: Script for not granting a promotion
quotes.text: When you, as a leader signal a lot, I care about you, I care about your feelings, I care that you're disappointed, I care about your career, you are always going to be able to help people stay resilient in the face of setbacks and ultimately, do extra work, do the right work for you and be engaged in your company because you've spent the time and energy making sure they know that even when things are not going their way, they have an ally in you.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Connects empathy to performance outcomes, framing “care” as a leadership lever for engagement after setbacks.

quotes.topic_title: Script for not granting a promotion
quotes.text: And it's not a problem to have the conversation right there then, but if there's a "Yes, I do, no, I don't, yes, I do, no, you don't," that pushback is never productive.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Offers a practical boundary: avoid unproductive point-counterpoint debates and steer toward a more constructive next step.

quotes.topic_title: Script for not granting a promotion
quotes.text: Listen, I totally hear you. You and I have a different point of view about this. I'm not sure if it's productive to continue to discussing right now. Let's talk about it again in a week. But I also want you to know this is a decision that I've made.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Provides a ready-to-use script for handling disagreement while preserving clarity, empathy, and decision finality.

quotes.topic_title: Pre-termination clarity: the final warning script
quotes.text: First of all, when you're firing someone, the hope is that it's not a surprise to them. You've had multiple conversations with them that they're not living up to your expectations. It's essential because the truth is, you want to create a culture where people are not surprised by being fired.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Sets a cultural standard: termination should be the predictable outcome of repeated, explicit feedback—not a shock event.

quotes.topic_title: Pre-termination clarity: the final warning script
quotes.text: The second thing is that before you fire someone, I think it's helpful to have the conversation before the firing conversation because something you said Lenny is like, "Oh, but maybe I'm wrong. Maybe I'm not sure." And that bleeds into, "Maybe I haven't been clear with this person."
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Introduces a pre-termination “clarity check” to separate manager uncertainty from employee performance and prevent avoidable firings.

quotes.topic_title: Pre-termination clarity: the final warning script
quotes.text: Regularly with my clients, I'll say, "Okay, have you been crystal clear about what you need from this person?" And what they always do is the hand motion like well, sort of, but well, maybe. Which means no, which means no.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic: any hedging about expectations is evidence you haven’t been clear enough to hold someone accountable.

quotes.topic_title: Pre-termination clarity: the final warning script
quotes.text: I need you to fix this within the next 30 days. Otherwise, I'm sorry to say, we're going to have to find a way to part ways because I can't keep this going with you.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Provides a concrete final-warning structure: specific behavior, deadline, and explicit consequence.

quotes.topic_title: Pre-termination clarity: the final warning script
quotes.text: But even if you do, it's actually easier because you've already had the conversation. Right? They're not surprised. It's clear. We've had the discussion.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Reframes the goal of the pre-termination talk: it makes outcomes (improvement or exit) cleaner and less emotionally volatile.

quotes.topic_title: The termination conversation and logistics handoff
quotes.text: But the conversation is actually very simple, which is just, "Matilda, we talked about this multiple times. The last time we had this conversation, I told you I needed you to make these changes. You haven't made these changes and we're going to part ways. So I have here, Sarah from HR or whatever, and we're going to talk through the logistics of that. I'm happy to have a longer conversation with you, but I want you to know we've made the decision to terminate you."
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A concise, actionable termination script that anchors on prior feedback, states the decision plainly, and hands off logistics to HR.

quotes.topic_title: The termination conversation and logistics handoff
quotes.text: Well, the script for doing the firing is again, please everybody, talk to your HR professional. Talk to your lawyer. Okay, I'm not a lawyer, I'm afraid. So you have to make sure that you're all buttoned up on what you're going to do.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A practical reminder to ensure HR/legal alignment before a termination conversation to reduce risk and ambiguity.

quotes.topic_title: The termination conversation and logistics handoff
quotes.text: What I call them is sort of delicate conversations because what I think people also shy away from is just simple praise, specific praise.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Reframes “difficult conversations” as “delicate conversations,” emphasizing that giving specific praise is also a leadership skill people avoid.

quotes.topic_title: The termination conversation and logistics handoff
quotes.text: And I think it's really important to get in the habit of pointing out what your people are doing well as carefully as you need to prepare for pointing out what they need to improve.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to apply the same preparation rigor to positive feedback as to corrective feedback.

quotes.topic_title: The termination conversation and logistics handoff
quotes.text: One time a leader or a manager I was doing in a training program, she said, "I don't like getting positive feedback. I only like getting negative feedback."
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A memorable example showing how some people undervalue positive feedback, which can skew feedback culture toward only criticism.

quotes.topic_title: Positive feedback as a leadership skill
quotes.text: What I call them is sort of delicate conversations because what I think people also shy away from is just simple praise, specific praise.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Reframes “difficult conversations” to include giving specific praise, highlighting a common leadership blind spot.

quotes.topic_title: Positive feedback as a leadership skill
quotes.text: And I think it's really important to get in the habit of pointing out what your people are doing well as carefully as you need to prepare for pointing out what they need to improve.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Actionable advice to apply the same rigor to positive feedback as to constructive feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Positive feedback as a leadership skill
quotes.text: So the positive feedback should have the same standard, which is, "I saw the way you ran that launch, it was fantastic. All these different benefits came from it. You're so organized, keep doing that."
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Provides a concrete template for behavior-linked praise that names actions, impact, and what to repeat.

quotes.topic_title: Positive feedback as a leadership skill
quotes.text: If you do that often enough, you do get in the... First of all, it's positive, obviously. You become in the habit of getting better at positive feedback, which is extremely motivating to people at work.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Emphasizes that positive feedback is a learnable skill and a high-leverage motivator when practiced consistently.

quotes.topic_title: Positive feedback as a leadership skill
quotes.text: She knows where she stands, and then one day, if you have to give her these difficult messages, you've already sort of laid the reservoir of goodwill.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Introduces the “reservoir of goodwill” mental model: frequent specific praise builds trust that makes hard feedback easier later.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With ready-made collaborative features, you can supercharge your product with experiences that only top tier companies have been able to perfect until now.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a practical approach—using prebuilt collaboration features—to quickly reach “best-in-class” product experiences.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Think AI copilots like Notion, multiplayer like Figma, comments and notifications like Linear and even collaborative editing like Google Docs, and all of that with minimal configuration or maintenance required.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides concrete examples of collaboration patterns teams can emulate, emphasizing low implementation overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Companies from all kinds of industries and stages count on Liveblocks to drive engagement and growth in their products.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Suggests a generalizable growth lever—collaboration features—as applicable across company sizes and sectors.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Join them today and give your users an experience that turns them into daily active users.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames a clear outcome metric (DAUs) tied to improving the user experience through collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders shouldn’t optimize for employee happiness
quotes.text: But what really needs to happen very often is, we need to drive towards results.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Reframes a leader’s primary job from keeping people happy to focusing the team on outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders shouldn’t optimize for employee happiness
quotes.text: Ultimately, that leads to the demise of your company.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Highlights the high stakes of avoiding hard feedback and tolerating underperformance.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders shouldn’t optimize for employee happiness
quotes.text: I think what that comes from is winning culture, which means we're set up for success.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Introduces a “winning culture” as the root driver of engagement rather than happiness-optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders shouldn’t optimize for employee happiness
quotes.text: We've got the structure for success, we have the culture for success, everyone understands their role, they know the impact of their role.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Gives concrete components leaders can build to create clarity and accountability at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders shouldn’t optimize for employee happiness
quotes.text: And when you create that kind of a workforce, I think it's much more dynamic, even though sometimes in doing that, you have to redirect people and ruffle their feathers.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Normalizes that building a high-performing culture requires discomfort and course-correction, not constant harmony.

quotes.topic_title: Perks vs performance: the avocado toast story
quotes.text: Sometimes I think to myself, if I'm writing a book, the book would start with, "It all started with the avocado toast," because he wants to do right by his workforce.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Memorable framing that highlights how well-intended perks can become the starting point of broader cultural and execution issues.

quotes.topic_title: Perks vs performance: the avocado toast story
quotes.text: And it became this great ritual where people would kind of hang out together and that was great.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Shows how positive social rituals can be genuinely beneficial—setting up the later contrast with performance and clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Perks vs performance: the avocado toast story
quotes.text: And then that turned into other longer periods of just hanging out together.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Illustrates the slippery slope where morale-boosting rituals expand into unbounded social time that can crowd out work.

quotes.topic_title: Perks vs performance: the avocado toast story
quotes.text: but they continued to be not fully clear on what they were actually supposed to do.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: Pinpoints the core operational failure: perks can’t compensate for lack of role clarity and expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Perks vs performance: the avocado toast story
quotes.text: So rather than talk about expectations about the work and about results, and again, the results were not showing.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.context: A practical warning that avoiding explicit performance conversations often correlates with weak outcomes.
